tasks.description: Accept and validate a website URL from the user.
Retrieve the website’s HTTP response, headers, and content.
Measure performance metrics such as load time, response size, compression, and caching headers.
Assess usability factors including mobile friendliness, accessibility, and page structure.
Compute performance, usability, and overall grades based on collected data.
Compile a comprehensive report with metrics, visualizations, and improvement recommendations.
Render the report in a user‑friendly web interface.
Persist report data for history and comparison.
Expose an API endpoint for programmatic access to grading results.
Implement monitoring and logging for service reliability.
Authenticate user with Fitbit OAuth 2.0 and obtain access tokens.
Retrieve daily activity data (steps, calories, distance, active minutes) from the Fitbit API.
Persist retrieved activity data in a local or cloud database for offline access and historical analysis.
Display activity summaries, trends, and visualizations in the app’s dashboard.
Allow users to set personal activity goals and track progress against those goals.
Send push notifications or reminders when users reach milestones or need encouragement.
Handle data synchronization, token refresh, and conflict resolution between local and Fitbit data.
Retrieve and store legislative voting data from a public API or dataset.
Retrieve and store campaign finance data from a public API or dataset.
Normalize and clean both datasets (standardize identifiers, dates, amounts).
Map contributions to bills by linking donors to recipients and recipients to bills.
Compute influence metrics such as contribution-to-vote ratios and contribution density per bill.
Design and expose RESTful endpoints for querying bills, contributions, and influence scores.
Build a front‑end dashboard that visualizes bills, votes, and associated contributions with filtering and sorting.
Implement caching, pagination, and rate‑limit handling for external API calls and internal queries.
Set up authentication/authorization for API access and user sessions.
Establish data update pipelines to keep voting and finance data current.
Implement user authentication and role‑based access control.
Design and build the event management module (create, edit, delete events).
Develop the timing capture subsystem (receive lap times, handle time stamps).
Create the scoring engine (apply race rules, calculate points, handle penalties).
Generate and display results tables and leaderboards in real time.
Build the MotorsportReg.com integration to import T&S data via API with one‑click.
Implement data export features (CSV, PDF, JSON) for results and timing logs.
Design the database schema to store events, participants, timing, and scoring data.
Develop the front‑end UI components for timing input, scoring review, and results display.
Set up automated testing, CI/CD pipelines, and deployment scripts for the platform.
Authenticate and authorize with Constant Contact API.
Build a user interface for creating and configuring subscription boxes (fields, styling, options).
Generate a reusable embed code snippet that can be placed on any website.
Handle form submissions on the client side and forward data to Constant Contact.
Store captured leads locally or sync them with Constant Contact for backup.
Provide basic analytics (number of submissions, conversion rates).
Implement validation, error handling, and user feedback.
Create documentation and support resources for users.
Detect the user’s geographic location using IP geolocation or browser geolocation APIs.
Fetch current weather and forecast data from external weather APIs (e.g., OpenWeatherMap, WeatherAPI).
Aggregate and reconcile data from multiple sources to improve accuracy and fill gaps.
Cache retrieved data locally (e.g., in-memory or localStorage) to reduce API calls and improve load times.
Design and implement a simple visual dashboard that displays current conditions, short‑term forecast, and weather icons.
Implement robust error handling, including fallback data sources and user notifications for API failures.
Optimize performance by debouncing location requests, lazy‑loading UI components, and minimizing network traffic.
Retrieve NCAA campaign metadata (dates, PSA schedule, campaign goals).
Fetch DonorsChoose.org donation records for K-12 districts linked to the campaign.
Map school districts to geographic coordinates and administrative boundaries.
Aggregate donation totals and compute metrics (average donation, number of projects funded) per district.
Provide search and filter capabilities by district, state, or school type.
Integrate PSA media assets (video URLs, thumbnails) into the data model.
Generate analytics dashboards (maps, charts, trend analysis) for campaign performance.
Expose RESTful API endpoints for external applications to consume campaign and donation data.
Implement authentication and rate‑limiting for secure API access.
Cache frequently accessed data to improve performance and reduce external API calls.
Initiate the conference scheduling workflow and trigger the process at the scheduled time.
Contact the meeting originator via phone or email to confirm that the meeting is still scheduled.
Verify the meeting status, time, and any special requirements before proceeding.
Retrieve the list of registered participant phone numbers from the database.
Attempt to place conference calls to each participant using a telephony API.
Monitor call attempts, detect failures, and record call status for each participant.
Generate a temporary call‑in number and a secure PIN for participants who could not be reached.
Send SMS notifications containing the temporary call‑in number and PIN to the participants’ cell phones.
Manage the conference bridge connection, routing participants into the call once they answer.
Log all events, call attempts, failures, and notifications for audit and troubleshooting.
Authenticate with Gmail via OAuth 2.0 and obtain necessary scopes.
Retrieve email metadata (subject, sender, labels, timestamps) from Gmail API.
Compute inbox zero status by analyzing unread, starred, important, and other labels.
Design gamification mechanics: points, levels, streaks, challenges.
Implement reward system: virtual badges, points, or integration with external reward platforms.
Create browser extension UI: sidebar or popup to display game stats and rewards.
Persist user progress and reward data securely (local storage or backend).
Send notifications or reminders to encourage inbox zero maintenance.
Log analytics: email activity, user engagement, reward redemption.
Ensure compliance with Gmail API usage limits and privacy policies.
Implement user authentication and role management for leaders and members.
Develop group creation, membership management, and role assignment features.
Create event scheduling, calendar integration, and event notification capabilities.
Build a message composition interface for group leaders.
Implement multi‑channel message dispatch to SMS, email, phone, and social media.
Track delivery status and provide reporting for dispatched messages.
Develop the web application front‑end for group leaders.
Develop the iPad application front‑end for group leaders.
Allow members to set and update their communication preferences.
Integrate with an SMS gateway API (e.g., Twilio) for text messaging.
Integrate with an email service provider (e.g., SendGrid) for email delivery.
Integrate with a phone call API (e.g., Twilio Voice) for voice communication.
Integrate with social media APIs (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) for posting and messaging.
Implement push notification system for real‑time alerts.
Design database schema and implement data persistence for users, groups, events, and messages.
Ensure security, privacy compliance, and audit logging across all components.
Implement secure user authentication and role-based access control for staff.
Create, edit, and delete waitlists for different business locations or tables.
Allow patrons to join the waitlist by entering name and phone number, assign queue position, and display estimated wait time.
Integrate with an SMS gateway to automatically send text notifications when a patron is next.
Provide real‑time updates to staff and patrons on queue status and estimated wait times.
Generate analytics reports on average wait times, peak periods, and queue performance.
Offer an admin dashboard for configuring SMS provider credentials, notification thresholds, and other system settings.
Ensure secure data persistence for patron and queue information, following best practices for data protection.
Authenticate with Twitter API using OAuth 2.0 to access the user’s timeline and media.
Retrieve the latest tweets (text, images, videos) from the authenticated user’s timeline.
Process tweet content: convert text to speech or subtitles, and prepare media assets for video composition.
Compose a short video clip from the processed assets, applying a predefined “classic” visual filter or style.
Authenticate with YouTube Data API using OAuth 2.0 to obtain upload permissions.
Upload the composed video to YouTube, setting appropriate metadata (title, description, tags).
Post a tweet containing the YouTube video link and a brief caption, using the Twitter API.
Implement error handling and logging for each step to ensure reliability and traceability.
Integrate MyPhoneTap API for call routing and recording initiation.
Implement billing logic to charge 15¢ per minute, track usage, and enforce the two‑minute free trial.
Convert raw recorded audio from MyPhoneTap into MP3 format for delivery.
Store MP3 recordings securely and provide retrieval endpoints for users.
Add caller notification prompts where legally required to inform about recording.
Build a user interface/dashboard for users to view, download, and manage their recordings.
Create a compliance module that checks jurisdictional laws and triggers notifications accordingly.
Set up monitoring, logging, and alerting for call routing, billing, and recording failures.
Develop API endpoints for third‑party integration (e.g., billing systems, CRM).
Deploy the service to a scalable cloud environment and perform end‑to‑end testing.
Implement OAuth 2.0 authentication flow with Box to obtain an access token.
Use the Box API to fetch the user’s file list and display it in the ActivePrint interface.
Provide a preview mechanism for selected Box files (e.g., PDF, image, document).
Download the selected file to local storage or a temporary cache.
Create and send an AirPrint job with the downloaded file to the selected printer.
Monitor the print job status and update the UI with success or failure notifications.
Handle network errors, authentication failures, and file format issues gracefully.
Manage token refresh and secure storage of credentials.
Implement caching and offline support for previously accessed files.
Ensure compliance with privacy and data protection standards for user files.
Authenticate the user with Box using OAuth 2.0 to obtain access to their file storage.
Authenticate the user with Fuze Meeting using OAuth 2.0 to gain permissions for meeting creation and file sharing.
Retrieve the list of files and folders from the user's Box account via the Box API.
Allow the user to select one or more files for sharing within the Fuze Meeting.
Download the selected file(s) from Box or generate a secure shareable link.
Upload the file(s) to Fuze Meeting's file storage or attach the Box share link to the meeting.
Create or join a Fuze Meeting session, ensuring the meeting is accessible to all intended participants.
Insert the file link or attachment into the Fuze Meeting chat or shared workspace for collaborative discussion.
Notify meeting participants of the new file share via chat message or meeting notification.
Handle errors and edge cases such as authentication failures, file size limits, and network interruptions.
Log activity for audit and analytics, capturing file transfer events and meeting usage.
Design a responsive, mobile-first UI for the Key Metrics Change widget that adapts to iPhone screen sizes and orientations.
Implement data fetching logic to retrieve key metrics from the youcalc analytics API, including handling pagination and real‑time updates.
Add authentication and authorization mechanisms (e.g., OAuth 2.0 or API keys) to ensure only authorized administrators can access the widget data.
Create an embeddable widget component (e.g., a JavaScript snippet or iframe) that can be inserted into any web page or mobile app.
Optimize performance for mobile: minify assets, enable lazy loading of charts, and reduce network latency with CDN caching.
Test the widget on iPhone Safari and other mobile browsers to ensure visual fidelity, responsiveness, and correct data rendering.
Document usage instructions, API endpoints, and embedding guidelines for developers and administrators.
Deploy the widget assets to a CDN, set up monitoring for uptime and usage analytics, and establish a feedback loop for continuous improvement.
Retrieve historical market data from the Betfair API.
Parse and transform Betfair data into a structured format suitable for BIRT.
Design and maintain BIRT report templates for various analytics views.
Generate BIRT charts (e.g., line, bar, pie) based on the transformed data.
Compile BIRT reports and export them to desired formats such as PDF, HTML, or Excel.
Implement scheduling and automation for periodic report generation.
Expose API endpoints or interfaces for consuming the generated reports.
Implement Flickr OAuth authentication to obtain user access tokens.
Fetch the authenticated user’s photo library via Flickr API.
Build a photo gallery UI that lets users select photos for the calendar.
Provide a catalog of calendar templates and allow users to choose one.
Develop a layout engine that arranges selected photos into the chosen template.
Generate the final calendar as a downloadable PDF or image file.
Offer sharing options (email, social media, direct link).
Create a responsive front‑end interface for the entire workflow.
Set up a back‑end service to handle API calls, image processing, and file storage.
Provide a user interface for selecting a Flickr feed (enter username, feed URL, or choose from a list of popular feeds).
Retrieve the selected Flickr feed data via the Flickr API or RSS feed endpoint.
Parse the feed response to extract image URLs, titles, and links for each photo.
Generate the scrolling ticker markup (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript) that displays the parsed images in a continuous horizontal scroll.
Provide the user with an embed code snippet (e.g., a <script> tag or iframe) that can be copied and pasted into their website to display the ticker.
Design the recipe data model with fields for title, cuisine, region, ingredients, steps, images, nutrition, and source URL.
Integrate with a recipe API (e.g., Spoonacular, Edamam) to fetch recipe data.
Implement search functionality that accepts keywords, cuisine, region, and ingredient filters.
Add specialized filters for South Indian and North Indian recipes.
Build UI components for recipe listing, detail view, and navigation.
Provide nutritional information display and calculation.
Implement user authentication and profile management for saving favorites.
Cache popular recipes and search results to improve performance.
Handle API rate limits and error handling gracefully.
Add localization support for multiple languages (e.g., English, Hindi, Tamil).
Authenticate with Google Apps using OAuth 2.0 and obtain an access token for the Email Migration API.
Connect to Microsoft Outlook data store and retrieve emails, calendar events, contacts, and tasks.
Map Outlook data structures to the corresponding Google Apps data models.
Upload emails to Gmail using the Email Migration API.
Upload calendar events to Google Calendar via the Calendar API.
Upload contacts to Google Contacts via the People API.
Upload tasks to Google Tasks via the Tasks API.
Implement error handling and retry logic for API failures and data inconsistencies.
Provide progress reporting, logging, and status dashboards for the migration process.
Design a user interface for configuration, authentication, and monitoring of migration jobs.
Perform validation and data integrity checks after migration to ensure completeness.
Package, test, and deploy the migration utility as a standalone application.
Retrieve the full list of DBpedia concepts.
For each concept, fetch multilingual labels from DBpedia/Wikipedia.
For each concept, fetch geographic coordinates from Wikipedia.
Construct a search query string combining labels and coordinates.
Query the Flickr API with the constructed query, handling pagination.
Respect Flickr API rate limits and implement retry/backoff logic.
Store the retrieved photo metadata in a structured database, linking each photo to its DBpedia concept.
Index the stored data to enable efficient retrieval and analysis.
Implement error handling, logging, and monitoring for the entire pipeline.
Provide a cleanup and archival routine for old or unused data.
User authentication and authorization (OAuth, JWT, social login).
Group management: create, edit, delete groups and assign group admins.
Event/activity creation within a group, including details, dates, and budget limits.
Invite and manage participants: send invites, accept/decline, and track participation status.
Contribution management: record deposits, track balances, and allow multiple payment methods.
Expense recording and splitting: add expenses, split equally or custom shares, and update group balances.
Payment integration: connect to banking APIs, digital wallets, and payment processors for real‑time transfers.
Notification and messaging: email, push, and in‑app alerts for invites, contributions, and expense updates.
Reporting and analytics: generate transaction history, balance sheets, and visual dashboards for group admins.
Security and compliance: data encryption, audit logging, and adherence to financial regulations.
Retrieve the latest Digg stories via the Digg API or RSS feed.
Parse the retrieved feed to extract story metadata (title, link, content, images, digg count).
Filter stories based on the user‑defined minimum digg threshold.
Limit the number of stories to the user‑defined display count.
Render the widget UI, displaying each story’s content and images.
Provide a preferences interface for setting the minimum digg count and item display count.
Implement caching of fetched data to reduce API calls and improve performance.
Handle errors gracefully, falling back to cached data when the feed cannot be retrieved.
Ensure the widget layout is responsive and works across different devices and screen sizes.
Set up a periodic refresh mechanism to update the feed at a configurable interval.
Authenticate with Flickr API and retrieve geotagged photos based on user, tag, or collection parameters.
Parse Flickr API responses to extract photo metadata, including latitude, longitude, title, URL, and owner information.
Implement client‑side filtering logic to allow users to refine results by user name, tag, or collection ID.
Render an interactive map (using Flash or a modern mapping library) with markers positioned at each photo’s geolocation.
Create a rich visual interface: display photo thumbnails on marker hover, provide a detail panel on click, and support zoom/pan interactions.
Handle pagination and lazy loading of photo data to maintain performance and reduce memory usage.
Implement caching and rate‑limit handling to respect Flickr API limits and improve response times.
Ensure cross‑browser compatibility and responsive design for various screen sizes, including mobile devices.
